[Page 4] A Message from Our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and Lead Director April 1, 2024 Dear Fellow Stockholders, On behalf of the Board of Directors (the “Board”) and the Executive Leadership Team, we are pleased to invite you to participate in the 2024 Annual Meeting of Stockholders (the “Annual Meeting”). [Page 4] The meeting will take place virtually on Tuesday, May 14, 2024, at 9:00 a.m. [Page 4] Central Daylight Time. [Page 4] There will be no in-person meeting. [Page 4] The attached Notice of the 2024 Annual Meeting of Stockholders and Proxy Statement provides information about the business we plan to conduct. [Page 4] A Compelling 10-Year Plan At our 2023 Analyst & Investor Meeting, we reaffirmed our durable returns-focused value proposition with an updated 10-year financial plan that produces solid free cash flow, allowing us to reward stockholders now and into the future. [Page 4] As we enter 2024, ConocoPhillips continues to be guided by our Triple Mandate, which sets out three objectives to align our actions with the underlying realities of our business and demonstrates our commitment to create long-term value for our stockholders. [Page 4] First, we must reliably and responsibly deliver oil and gas production to meet energy transition pathway demand. [Page 4] Second, we must deliver competitive returns on and of capital for our stockholders. [Page 4] Third, we must remain focused on achieving our net-zero operational emissions ambition. [Page 4] Our Triple Mandate underlies our clearly defined value proposition of delivering superior returns through price cycles based on our foundational principles of balance sheet strength, peer- leading distributions, disciplined investments, and responsible and reliable environmental, social and governance performance. [Page 4] Continuing to Deliver on Each Pillar of The Triple Mandate In 2023, we continued to deliver on each of the three mandates: First, we achieved record full-year Lower 48 and total Company production, enhanced our diverse portfolio, and progressed our global LNG strategy. [Page 4] In 2023, we delivered operationally across our diverse global portfolio with record full- year production of 1,826 MBOED. [Page 4] We continued to leverage technologies and operational excellence to improve drilling and completion efficiencies in the Lower 48 and across our assets. [Page 4] Our teams reached first production at several subsea tiebacks in Norway, Surmont Pad 267 in Canada and Bohai Phase 4B in China and achieved startup at the second phase of Montney’s central processing facility in Canada. [Page 4] We opportunistically acquired the remaining 50% working interest in Surmont at an attractive price that fits our financial framework. [Page 4] Long-life, low sustaining capital assets like Surmont play an important role in our low cost of supply portfolio. [Page 4] In addition, we reached final investment decision (FID) on Willow in Alaska, where we have over 50 years as a proven, responsible operator. [Page 4] Finally, we continued to advance our global LNG strategy through expansion in Qatar, FID at Port Arthur LNG, regasification agreements in the Netherlands and offtake agreements in Mexico. [Page 4] We now have equity, offtake, and regasification agreements across major global markets. [Page 4] Second, we returned $11 billion to stockholders and maintained discipline on our cost of supply framework with a continued focus on returns on and of capital. [Page 4] Full year 2023 earnings were $11.0 billion, or $9.06 per share, and our net cash provided by operating activities totaled $20.0 billion. [Page 4] We returned $11.0 billion to stockholders through our three-tier framework, including $5.6 billion through our ordinary dividend and variable return of cash and $5.4 billion in share repurchases. [Page 4] This is in excess of our annual through- the-cycle commitment to return greater than 30% of cash provided by operating activities to stockholders. [Page 4] In addition, across our portfolio we maintained discipline on our rigorous cost of supply framework to maximize our returns on capital. [Page 4] We are resolute in our efforts S SAFETY No task is so important that we can’t take the time to do it safely. [Page 4] A safe company is a successful company. [Page 4] P PEOPLE We respect one another. [Page 4] We recognize that our success depends upon the capabilities and inclusion of our employees. [Page 4] We value different voices and opinions. [Page 4] I INTEGRITY We are ethical and trustworthy in our relationships with internal and external stakeholders. [Page 4] We keep our promises. [Page 4] R RESPONSIBILITY We are accountable for our actions. [Page 4] We care about our neighbors. [Page 4] Sustainability is core to our company and creates shared value for our stakeholders. [Page 4] I INNOVATION We anticipate change and respond with creative solutions. [Page 4] We are responsive to the changing needs of the industry. [Page 4] We embrace learning. [Page 4] We are not afraid to try new things. [Page 4] T TEAMWORK We have a “can do” attitude that inspires top performance from everyone. [Page 4] We encourage collaboration. [Page 4] We celebrate success. [Page 4] We win together. [Page 4] 4 ConocoPhillips [Page 5] to maximize efficiencies and optimize well construction and completions designs to increase well recovery while minimizing incremental cost of supply. [Page 5] As an example, we achieved improvement of completion pumping efficiencies by 10% to 15% across our Lower 48 business segment. [Page 5] Third, we accelerated our company’s greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions-intensity reduction target through 2030 and were recognized by the Oil & Gas Methane Partnership 2.0 for our methane reduction efforts. [Page 5] In 2023, we demonstrated meaningful progress toward our Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition, including by accelerating our Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions-intensity reduction target from 40-50% to 50-60% gross operated emissions, using a 2016 baseline. [Page 5] We allocated a portion of our budget for projects to reduce our Scope 1 and 2 emissions intensity and advance low carbon opportunities, including carbon capture and storage. [Page 5] In addition, we are in our second year of membership in the Oil & Gas Methane Partnership 2.0 (OGMP 2.0) initiative, which seeks to improve industry transparency in methane emissions reporting and encourage progress in reducing those emissions. [Page 5] We were awarded the OGMP 2.0’s Gold Standard Pathway designation in recognition of our ambitious multi-year measurement-based reporting plan which goes beyond current regulatory requirements. [Page 5] Additionally, 2023 marked the first year that Energy Transition Milestones were included as a standalone metric in our Variable Cash Incentive Program, further demonstrating our commitment to our net-zero operational emissions ambitions, by directly tying our performance on the Energy Transition Milestones to our compensation. [Page 5] Looking to the Future Now and into the future, we are focused on operational excellence with a proven track record of strong returns. [Page 5] Our strategy is differential, and we believe our portfolio is the deepest, most durable and diverse of any of our peers. [Page 5] In addition, we are well positioned for the energy transition. [Page 5] Safety remains a critical part of our culture, and we prioritize the safety of both our colleagues and communities. [Page 5] That means continuously looking for ways to operate more safely, efficiently, and responsibly, with a focus on reducing human error. [Page 5] We understand that this is a fundamental part of our license to operate. [Page 5] Your input is valued and your vote is very important. [Page 5] We strongly believe that regular engagement with all stakeholders — stockholders, employees, customers, suppliers, advocacy groups, governments, and communities — is critical to our long-term success. [Page 5] The Annual Meeting is an opportunity for stockholders to express their views on ConocoPhillips’ business. [Page 5] Whether or not you plan to participate in the Annual Meeting, and no matter how many shares you own, we encourage you to vote in advance. [Page 5] Your vote is important to us and to our business. [Page 5] Prior to the meeting, you may sign and return your proxy card, use telephone or Internet voting, or visit the Annual Meeting website at www.conocophillips.com/annualmeeting to register your vote. [Page 5] Voting instructions begin on page 132. [Page 5] Thank you for your continued support. [Page 5] Ryan M. [Page 5] Lance Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Robert A. [Page 6] 6 ConocoPhillips [Page 7] Proxy Summary This summary highlights information contained elsewhere in this Proxy Statement. [Page 7] This summary does not contain all of the information that you should consider, and you should read the entire Proxy Statement carefully before voting. [Page 7] For more complete information regarding ConocoPhillips’ 2023 performance, please review our Annual Report. [Page 7] About ConocoPhillips Company Overview ConocoPhillips is one of the world’s leading exploration and production companies based on both production and reserves, with a globally diversified asset portfolio. [Page 7] Headquartered in Houston, Texas, as of December 31, 2023, ConocoPhillips had operations and activities in 13 countries, $96 billion of total assets, and approximately 9,900 employees. [Page 7] Production averaged 1,826 thousand barrels of oil equivalent per day (“MBOED”) in 2023, and proved reserves were 6.8 billion barrels of oil equivalent (“BBOE”) as of December 31, 2023. [Page 7] We explore for, produce, transport, and market crude oil, bitumen, natural gas, NGLs and LNG on a worldwide basis. [Page 7] Our diverse, low cost of supply portfolio includes resource-rich unconventional plays in North America; conventional assets in North America, Europe, Africa and Asia; LNG developments; oil sands in Canada; and an inventory of global exploration prospects. [Page 7] CONOCOPHILLIPS IS ONE OF THE WORLD’S LEADING E&P COMPANIES BASED ON BOTH PRODUCTION AND RESERVES, WITH A GLOBALLY DIVERSIFIED ASSET PORTFOLIO. summarization.introduction: This proxy statement provides information for the 2024 Annual Meeting of Stockholders, including details on director elections, executive compensation, and stockholder proposals. It also highlights ConocoPhillips' performance in 2023 and its strategic priorities.
summarization.main_points: The document details the agenda for the annual meeting, including proposals for the election of directors, ratification of the appointment of Ernst & Young LLP, advisory approval of executive compensation, and two stockholder proposals related to simple majority vote and revisiting pay incentives for GHG emission reductions. It also emphasizes ConocoPhillips' commitment to its Triple Mandate: reliably delivering oil and gas, providing competitive returns to stockholders, and achieving net-zero operational emissions. The company's 2023 achievements, including record production and progress on emissions reduction targets, are discussed, along with forward-looking statements and risk disclosures.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips encourages stockholders to vote and participate in the Annual Meeting, emphasizing the importance of stakeholder engagement for the company's long-term success. The company remains focused on operational excellence, safety, and responsible environmental, social, and governance performance.

chunk_text: [Page 8] Executing on our Returns-Focused Value Proposition Delivers Strong Financial and Operational Performance Throughout 2023, ConocoPhillips demonstrated that we can deliver strong financial and operational performance consistent with our value proposition of superior returns to stockholders through price cycles while executing against our Triple Mandate to reliably and responsibly deliver oil and gas production to meet energy transition pathway demand, deliver competitive returns on and of capital to our stockholders, and focus on achieving our net-zero operational emissions ambitions. [Page 8] • We delivered full year total and Lower 48 record production of 1,826 thousand barrels and 1,067 thousand barrels of oil equivalent per day, respectively, while we continued to enhance our portfolio diversity by opportunistically acquiring the remaining 50% working interest in Surmont, reaching FID on the Willow project in Alaska and further progressing our global LNG strategy. [Page 8] • We achieved a 17 percent return on capital employed(1) and we delivered competitive returns of capital by distributing $11 billion to stockholders through our three-tier framework, including $5.6 billion in cash through the ordinary dividend and variable return of cash (“VROC”) and $5.4 billion through share repurchases. [Page 8] • We continued to demonstrate our commitment to our net-zero operational emissions ambition by accelerating our GHG emissions-intensity reduction target through 2030 from 40-50% to 50-60%(2) and we were awarded the Oil & Gas Methane Partnership 2.0 Gold Standard Pathway designation. [Page 8] We continue to be guided by our SPIRIT Values and remain committed to our foundational principles — focusing on peer-leading distributions, maintaining a strong balance sheet, executing disciplined investment, and demonstrating responsible and reliable ESG performance. [Page 8] Supporting these core principles are our strategic cash flow allocation priorities: (1) invest enough capital to sustain production and pay the existing dividend; (2) grow the dividend annually; (3) maintain ‘A’ credit rating; (4) return greater than 30 percent of cash from operations to stockholders; and (5) make disciplined investments to enhance returns. [Page 8] A summary of the many important accomplishments we achieved in 2023 is shown below: 2023 HIGHLIGHTS — DELIVERING ACROSS ALL ELEMENTS OF THE TRIPLE MANDATE STRATEGY FINANCIAL OPERATIONS • Acquired remaining 50% working interest in Surmont • Progressed LNG strategy through expansion in Qatar, FID at PALNG, and regasification agreements in the Netherlands and offtake agreements in Mexico • Awarded Gold Standard Pathway designation by OGMP 2.0 • Accelerated GHG emissions- intensity reduction target through 2030(2) • Distributed $11B to stockholders; $5.6B in ordinary dividend and VROC and $5.4B in share repurchases • $11.0B earnings; $9.06 EPS; $10.6B adjusted earnings; $8.77 adjusted EPS(1) • Generated cash provided by operating activities of $20.0B; $21.3B CFO(3); $10.1B FCF(1); ending cash of $6.9B(4) • Announced 2024 expected return of capital of $9.0B • Delivered FY company and Lower 48 record production of 1,826 MBOED and 1,067 MBOED, respectively • Took FID on the Willow project • Achieved first production on projects in Norway, China and Canada • Improved completion pumping efficiencies by 10-15% across the Lower 48 (1) Adjusted earnings, adjusted EPS, return on capital employed (ROCE), and free cash flow (FCF) are non-GAAP measures. [Page 8] Further information related to these measures as well as reconciliations to the nearest GAAP measure are included in Appendix A. [Page 8] (2) Using a 2016 baseline. [Page 8] (3) Cash provided by operating activities was ~$20.0B. [Page 8] Excluding operating working capital change of ~($1.4B), cash from operations (CFO) was over $21.3B. [Page 8] CFO is a non-GAAP measure. [Page 8] Further information related to this measure is included in Appendix A. [Page 8] (4) Ending cash includes cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash totaling $5.9B and short-term investments of $1.0B. [Page 8] Restricted cash was $0.3B. [Page 8] Balance excludes $1.0B in long-term investments. [Page 8] 8 ConocoPhillips Proxy Summary [Page 9] We maintained our ongoing practice of engaging with stockholders throughout 2023 and received consistent feedback that our disciplined, returns-focused strategy is the right one for our business and that our stockholders appreciate our ongoing efforts to increase the transparency and robustness of our disclosures to address the things that they care about most. [Page 9] Stockholder Engagement ConocoPhillips understands the importance of maintaining a robust stockholder engagement program. [Page 9] During 2023, ConocoPhillips continued this long-standing practice. [Page 9] Executives and management from our investor relations, sustainable development, human resources, government affairs, and legal groups routinely engaged with stockholders on a variety of topics, including our strategy and value proposition, corporate governance, executive compensation, human capital management, culture, climate change, and sustainability. [Page 9] When appropriate, directors also met with stockholders. [Page 9] We spoke with representatives from our top institutional investors, mutual funds, public pension funds, labor unions, and socially responsible funds to hear their views on these important topics. [Page 9] Overall, investors expressed strong support for ConocoPhillips. [Page 9] We believe our regular stockholder engagement was productive and provided an open exchange of ideas and perspectives for both ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 9] For more information, see “Stockholder Engagement and Board Responsiveness” beginning on page 45 and “2023 Say on Pay Vote Result, Stockholder Engagement, and Board Responsiveness” beginning on page 69. [Page 12] We have robust governance practices and procedures that support our strategy. [Page 12] To maintain and enhance independent oversight, our Board is focused on its composition and effectiveness and has implemented a number of measures for continuous improvement. [Page 12] The measures outlined below align our corporate governance structure with our strategic objectives and enable the Board to effectively communicate and execute our culture of compliance and rigorous risk management. [Page 12] COMPREHENSIVE, INTEGRATED GOVERNANCE PRACTICES Diverse, Skilled Board Balanced Board Refreshment Active Independent Oversight Candid Self-Evaluation • Our Board is committed to regular renewal and refreshment, and we continually assess whether our composition appropriately relates to ConocoPhillips’ current and evolving strategic needs. [Page 12] See “Board Composition and Refreshment” beginning on page 33. [Page 12] • In assessing Board composition, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs considers any planned retirements from the Board, as well as background and diversity (including gender, ethnicity, race, national origin, and geographic background). [Page 12] • As a result, we have an experienced and diverse group of nominees. [Page 12] See “How Are Nominees Selected?” beginning on page 16. [Page 12] • The Board balances its commitment to maintaining institutional knowledge with the need for fresh perspectives that board refreshment and director succession planning provide. [Page 12] • Our Board’s thorough onboarding and director education processes complement our recruitment process. [Page 12] See “Director Onboarding and Education” beginning on page 34. [Page 12] • Our independent Lead Director’s robust duties are set forth in our Corporate Governance Guidelines. [Page 12] See “Board Leadership Structure” beginning on page 36. [Page 12] • Our non-employee directors meet privately in executive session at each regularly scheduled Board meeting. [Page 12] • Our Board reviews CEO and senior management succession and development plans at least annually and assesses candidates during Board and committee meetings and in less formal settings. [Page 12] • Our Board and committees conduct intensive and thoughtful annual evaluations of the Board, its committees, and its directors, including self-evaluations and peer assessments. [Page 12] See “Board and Committee Evaluations” on page 35. [Page 12] • Our directors provide feedback on Board and committee effectiveness, including areas such as Board composition and the Board/management succession-planning process. [Page 12] • Our Board regularly assesses its leadership structure. [Page 12] • Our Board’s decision-making is informed by input from stockholders. [Page 12] The governance best practices we have adopted support these general principles: • Annual election of all directors • Long-standing commitment to sustainability • Stock ownership guidelines for directors and executives • Independent Audit and Finance, Human Resources and Compensation, Public Policy and Sustainability, and Directors’ Affairs committees • Transparent public policy engagement • Prohibition on pledging and hedging for all employees • Proxy access • Active stockholder engagement • Majority independent Board • Executive sessions of non-employee directors held at each regularly scheduled Board meeting • Empowered independent Lead Director • Majority vote standard in uncontested elections • Clawback Policy 12 ConocoPhillips Proxy Summary [Page 13] Executive Compensation Compensation Designed Around our Strategy and Informed by Stockholder Feedback Our executive compensation programs and metrics are aligned with our Triple Mandate and directly tie to our strategic priorities (see page 72). [Page 13] The following chart summarizes the principal components of our executive compensation program (percentages are shown for each component of our CEO’s 2023 target compensation). [Page 13] VARIABLE CASH INCENTIVE PROGRAM (VCIP) 14% • One-year performance period - Health Safety & Environment (20%) - Operational (30%) - Financial (30%) - Strategic Milestones (10%) - Energy Transition Milestones (10%) Over 90% of CEO Compensation is Performance Based SALARY 9% • Market competitive; adjusted for experience, responsibility and performance EXECUTIVE RESTRICTED STOCK UNITS 27% • Long-term equity compensation designed to encourage executive retention and aligned with long-term value creation for stockholders (35% of long-term incentive value) - Settles in stock following 3rd anniversary of grant date PERFORMANCE SHARE PROGRAM (PSP) 50% • Performance and equity-based compensation to reward executives for achieving three-year performance targets (65% of long-term incentive value) - Relative Total Shareholder Return (60%) - Financial—Relative Adjusted ROCE (40%) Performance Metrics (VCIP & PSP) are aligned with the Triple Mandate and Company Strategy Each year the HRCC, advised by its independent compensation consultant and informed by feedback from stockholders, undertakes a rigorous process to review our programs. [Page 13] The HRCC believes a substantial portion of our executive compensation should be equity-based and focused on rewarding long-term performance and furthermore, that this approach most closely aligns the interests of our top executives with those of our stockholders (see page 67). [Page 13] Compensation and Governance Practices Through our robust process described under the heading “HRCC Annual Compensation Cycle” on page 78, the HRCC has adopted strong governance practices consistent with the market, some of which are summarized below. summarization.introduction: ConocoPhillips demonstrated strong financial and operational performance in 2023, delivering superior returns to stockholders while adhering to its Triple Mandate, which focuses on responsible energy production, competitive returns, and net-zero operational emissions. Executive compensation is aligned with the company's strategy and informed by stockholder feedback, with a focus on long-term performance and equity-based incentives. Furthermore, significant progress was made on their Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition with regards to strategic flexibility, Scope 1 and 2 emissions reduction, and offsets.

The company continues to refine its strategies and commitments through ongoing engagement with stakeholders, focusing on sustainable practices and transparent governance.

chunk_text: [Page 15] ADDRESSING END USE (SCOPE 3) EMISSIONS AND CONTRIBUTING TO THE ENERGY TRANSITION Advocacy and Public Policy • Expanded policy advocacy beyond carbon pricing to include energy efficiency, end-use emissions policy and regulatory action such as direct federal regulation of methane, and national policy recommendations on natural gas across the value chain. [Page 15] • Carbon pricing is the most effective and predictable policy action to reduce GHG emissions across the economy, so ConocoPhillips continues working with World Bank’s Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition as a private sector partner to share and expand the evidence base for effective carbon pricing in addition to our continued support of the Climate Leadership Council and Americans for Carbon Dividends in the U.S. [Page 15] Supply Chain Engagement • Hosted annual Supplier Sustainability Forum with a focus group of suppliers to identify opportunities to reduce emissions in our value chain. [Page 15] • Collaborated with industry groups and third-party partners to align on collection, reporting and supplier engagement for supplier emissions. [Page 15] LNG • Secured regasification capacity at the Gate LNG terminal in the Netherlands. [Page 15] • Secured 5 MTPA of LNG offtake along with 30% equity in Sempra’s Port Arthur LNG Phase 1 project on the U.S. [Page 15] Gulf Coast which began construction in March. [Page 15] • Signed offtake agreements at Mexico Pacific’s Saguaro LNG and Energia Costa Azul export facility on the west coast of Mexico. [Page 15] CCS & Hydrogen • Continued evaluation of potential opportunities to develop carbon capture and storage (CCS) hubs along the U.S. [Page 15] Gulf Coast. [Page 15] • Participating in Canada’s Oil Sands Pathways Alliance working toward net-zero operational emissions by 2050 through CCS. [Page 15] • Completed an equity investment in Avnos, a hybrid direct air capture innovator, and began evaluating the technology for project development. [Page 15] • Evaluating the development of blue and green ammonia as a low-carbon power generation fuel from the U.S. [Page 15] Gulf Coast with Japanese energy company JERA. [Page 15] We acknowledge the findings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change that GHG emissions from the use of fossil fuels contribute to increases in global temperatures. [Page 15] We acknowledge the importance that science places on limiting global average temperature increases to below 2-degree Celsius compared to pre-industrial times, and to achieve that, science shows that global GHG emissions need to reach net-zero in the second half of this century. [Page 15] We support the Paris Agreement as a welcomed global policy response to that challenge. [Page 15] We have had a public global climate change position since 2003. [Page 15] The position is reviewed periodically, agreed to by the Executive Leadership Team, and then recommended to the Board. [Page 15] 15 2024 Proxy Statement Progress Report on Our Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition [Page 16] Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies What am I Voting On? [Page 16] You are voting on a proposal to elect the 12 nominees named in this Proxy Statement to one-year terms as ConocoPhillips directors. [Page 16] What is the makeup of the Board of Directors and how often are the members elected? [Page 16] Our Board currently has 12 members. [Page 16] Directors are elected at the annual stockholder meeting each year. [Page 16] Any vacancy on the Board created between annual stockholder meetings (if, for example, a current director resigns or the size of the Board is increased) may be filled by a majority vote of the remaining directors then in office. [Page 16] Any director appointed to fill a vacancy would hold office until the next election. [Page 16] Under our Corporate Governance Guidelines, directors generally may not stand for reelection after they reach the age of 72. [Page 16] What if a nominee is unable or unwilling to serve? [Page 16] All director nominees have consented to serve. [Page 16] However, should a director become unable or unwilling to serve before the date of the Annual Meeting and should the Board not elect to reduce the size of the Board, shares represented by proxies may be voted for a substitute nominated by the Board. [Page 16] How are directors compensated? [Page 16] Please see our discussion of director compensation beginning on page 53. [Page 16] How are nominees selected? [Page 16] The Committee on Directors’ Affairs regularly evaluates the size and composition of the Board and continually assesses whether the composition appropriately relates to ConocoPhillips’ strategic needs, which change as the business environment evolves. [Page 16] We seek director candidates who possess the highest personal and professional ethics, integrity, and values and who are committed to representing the long-term interest of all ConocoPhillips’ stakeholders. [Page 16] As some directors approach retirement age, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs seeks to onboard new directors to backfill the needed skills and experience of outgoing directors with sufficient overlap in service to allow for the transfer of institutional knowledge and sharing of experiences. [Page 16] 16 ConocoPhillips [Page 17] The chart below shows our process for identifying and integrating new directors. [Page 17] HOW WE SELECT AND ONBOARD/INTEGRATE NEW BOARD MEMBERS Board assesses its current composition and identifies skills or characteristics needed to enhance its effectiveness, considering things like: • the company’s strategy • current director tenure • established retirement age • results of evaluations Candidates suggested by: • non- employee directors • stockholders • outside search firms • management Pool of candidates vetted based on: • qualifications • leadership experience • integrity, ethics, and judgment • diversity • independence • competing obligations and potential conflicts • mix of skills already on the Board Committee on Directors’ Affairs interviews promising candidates and recommends nominees to the full Board Board nominates candidates for election at next annual meeting or elects new members to serve until stockholders vote at next annual meeting New directors undergo orientation and training Members of the Board provide self- evaluations and evaluations of the full Board and committees Our Corporate Governance Guidelines contain director independence standards consistent with the standards prescribed in the NYSE Listed Company Manual and provide that, at all times, at least a substantial majority of the Board must meet those standards. [Page 17] The Committee on Directors’ Affairs also seeks to ensure that the Board reflects a range of talents, ages, skills, personal attributes, and expertise — particularly in the areas of leadership and management, financial reporting, issues specific to oil- and gas-related industries, both domestic and international markets, public policy and government regulation, technology, public company board service, human capital management, and environmental and sustainability matters — sufficient to provide sound and prudent guidance with respect to ConocoPhillips’ strategic needs. [Page 17] The Board seeks to maintain a diverse membership and also requires that its members be able to dedicate the time and resources necessary to ensure the diligent performance of their duties, including attending Board and applicable committee meetings. [Page 17] To that end, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs considers the number of other boards on which each candidate already serves. [Page 17] Non-employee directors may not serve on more than four other boards of publicly-traded companies in addition to the Board, and ConocoPhillips' Chief Executive Officer may not serve on the board of more than one other publicly-traded company. [Page 17] Directors should seek approval from the Chair of the Board and the Chair of the Committee on Directors’ Affairs in advance of accepting an invitation to serve on another public company board. [Page 18] These individuals have a demonstrated record of leadership and a practical understanding of organizations, processes, strategy, risk and risk management, and the methods to drive change and growth. [Page 18] Through their service as top leaders at other companies, they also bring valuable perspectives on common issues affecting large and complex organizations. [Page 18] We measure operating and strategic performance by reference to financial targets. [Page 18] In addition, accurate financial reporting and robust auditing are critical to ConocoPhillips’ success. [Page 18] Accordingly, we seek to have a number of directors who could qualify as audit committee financial experts (as defined by SEC rules), and we expect all of our directors to be financially knowledgeable. [Page 18] We also believe it is important to have knowledge and experience in capital markets, both debt and equity, given our position as a large publicly traded company. [Page 18] We seek to have directors with significant experience in the energy industry. [Page 18] These directors have valuable perspective on issues specific to our business. [Page 18] GLOBAL REGULATORY/GOVERNMENT TECHNOLOGY As a global energy company, our future success depends, in part, on how we grow our businesses outside the United States. [Page 18] Directors with global business or international experience provide valued perspectives on our operations. [Page 18] The perspectives of directors who have experience within the regulatory field are important. [Page 18] The energy industry is heavily regulated and directly affected by governmental actions and decisions, and we believe that directors with government experience offer valuable insight in this regard. [Page 18] Experience or expertise in information technology helps us pursue and achieve our business objectives. [Page 18] Leadership and understanding of technology, cybersecurity risk, cloud computing, scalable data analytics, and big data technologies add exceptional value to our Board as we increasingly utilize our global data assets to monitor and optimize our operations. [Page 18] PUBLIC COMPANY BOARD SERVICE ENVIRONMENTAL/ SUSTAINABILITY HUMAN CAPITAL MANAGEMENT ConocoPhillips aspires to the highest standards of corporate governance and ethical conduct. [Page 18] Service on the boards and board committees of other large, publicly traded companies provides an understanding of corporate governance practices and trends and insights into: (1) board management; (2) relations between the Board, the CEO, and senior management; (3) agenda setting; and (4) succession planning. [Page 18] We believe this experience supports our goals of strong board and management accountability, transparency, and protection of stockholder interests. [Page 18] Our sustainable development approach is integrated into ConocoPhillips’ planning and decision-making. [Page 18] Directors who have experience with sustainability, including through leadership roles in our industry, strengthen the Board’s oversight and ensure that strategic business essentials and long-term value creation for stockholders are achieved with a responsible, sustainable business model which fosters a stable and healthy environment for tomorrow and proactively addresses stakeholder interests. qa_pairs.question: What global agreement does ConocoPhillips support?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips supports the Paris Agreement.

qa_pairs.question: How long has ConocoPhillips had a public global climate change position?
qa_pairs.answer: Since 2003.

qa_pairs.question: How many directors does the ConocoPhillips Board currently have?
qa_pairs.answer: Our Board currently has 12 members.

qa_pairs.question: How often are directors elected?
qa_pairs.answer: Directors are elected at the annual stockholder meeting each year.

qa_pairs.question: What happens if a vacancy arises on the Board between annual stockholder meetings?
qa_pairs.answer: Any vacancy on the Board created between annual stockholder meetings may be filled by a majority vote of the remaining directors then in office. Any director appointed to fill a vacancy would hold office until the next election.

qa_pairs.question: What is the general age limit for directors standing for reelection?
qa_pairs.answer: Under our Corporate Governance Guidelines, directors generally may not stand for reelection after they reach the age of 72.

qa_pairs.question: What is the process for selecting director nominees?
qa_pairs.answer: The Committee on Directors’ Affairs regularly evaluates the size and composition of the Board and continually assesses whether the composition appropriately relates to ConocoPhillips’ strategic needs, which change as the business environment evolves. They seek candidates with high ethics, integrity, values and who are committed to representing the long-term interest of all ConocoPhillips’ stakeholders.

qa_pairs.question: What criteria does the Board assess when identifying needed skills or characteristics?
qa_pairs.answer: The board assesses its current composition and identifies skills or characteristics needed to enhance its effectiveness, considering things like: the company’s strategy, current director tenure, established retirement age, results of evaluations.

qa_pairs.question: What factors are candidates vetted on?
qa_pairs.answer: Pool of candidates vetted based on: qualifications, leadership experience, integrity, ethics, and judgment, diversity, independence, competing obligations and potential conflicts, mix of skills already on the Board

qa_pairs.question: What areas of expertise does the Committee on Directors' Affairs seek to ensure the Board reflects?
qa_pairs.answer: Leadership and management, financial reporting, issues specific to oil- and gas-related industries, both domestic and international markets, public policy and government regulation, technology, public company board service, human capital management, and environmental and sustainability matters.

qa_pairs.question: How many other public boards can Non-employee directors serve on?
qa_pairs.answer: Non-employee directors may not serve on more than four other boards of publicly-traded companies in addition to the Board.

qa_pairs.question: How many other public boards can ConocoPhillips' CEO serve on?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips' Chief Executive Officer may not serve on the board of more than one other publicly-traded company.

qa_pairs.question: What skills are considered when evaluating director nominees?
qa_pairs.answer: CEO or senior officer, Financial reporting, Industry, Global, Regulatory/government, Technology, Public company board service, Environmental/sustainability, Human capital management

qa_pairs.question: How are candidates generally identified for the Board of Directors?
qa_pairs.answer: Generally, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs identifies candidates through business and organizational contacts of the directors and management.

qa_pairs.question: How can stockholders recommend director candidates?
qa_pairs.answer: Stockholders are also welcomed to recommend director candidates for consideration by following the procedures described under “Submission of Future Stockholder Proposals and Nominations” on page 129 for nominations made directly by a stockholder.

qa_pairs.question: What vote is required to approve the director nominees?
qa_pairs.answer: Each nominee requires the affirmative vote of a majority of the votes cast at the Annual Meeting; the number of votes cast “for” a director must exceed the number of votes cast “against” that director.

qa_pairs.question: What happens if a Director Nominee does not receive a majority of the votes cast?
qa_pairs.answer: If a nominee who is serving as a director is not elected at the Annual Meeting and no one else is elected in place of that director, then, under Delaware law, the director continues to serve on the Board as a “holdover director.” However, under our By-Laws, a holdover director is required to tender a resignation to the Board.

qa_pairs.question: How many directors are standing for election?
qa_pairs.answer: The following 12 directors are standing for election to hold office until the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders.

qa_pairs.question: What are Dennis V. Arriola's current affiliations?
qa_pairs.answer: Mr. Arriola is an Operating Partner at Sandbrook Capital and serves on the board of directors of Meritage Homes, Commercial Metals Company, and the Automobile Club of Southern California.

qa_pairs.question: What skills and qualifications does Dennis V. Arriola bring to the board?
qa_pairs.answer: Mr. Arriola’s extensive experience in the energy sector, including leadership positions in companies with global operations in gas and electric utilities as well as renewables, brings valuable perspective to the Board. [Page 33] In 2023, the Board undertook a search for qualified female candidates that could bring the right skills and experience to enhance the Board’s composition. [Page 33] A great deal of rigor and care is put into the Board refreshment process, which requires time for director selection and onboarding. [Page 33] Nonetheless, we are committed to onboarding at least one new female director by the end of 2024. [Page 33] As part of our Board’s commitment to regular renewal and refreshment: • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs routinely and on an ongoing basis assesses the Board’s composition, taking into consideration any planned retirements for the Board, as well as background and diversity (including gender, ethnicity, race, national origin, and geographic background); • We have implemented an annual Board and Committee assessment process; and • We have adopted Corporate Governance Guidelines that state that directors generally may not stand for re-election after they reach the age of 72. [Page 33] Five of the 12 director nominees have joined the Board in the past 5 years. [Page 33] Almost 42 percent of our director nominees are women or racially/ ethnically diverse individuals. [Page 33] The average age of our director nominees is 63 and the average tenure of our director nominees is 6 years. [Page 33] Board Changes in the Past 5 Years 5 new highly skilled directors have joined our Board 4 directors have left our Board Skills enhanced in the past 5 years CEO or senior officer experience Industry experience ­ Expertise in environmental matters and sustainability Global organization experience 33 2024 Proxy Statement Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 34] Director Onboarding and Education The Board has an orientation and onboarding program for new directors and provides continuing education for all directors that is overseen by the Committee on Directors’ Affairs. [Page 34] New Director Orientation The orientation program is tailored to the needs of each new director depending on his or her level of experience serving on other boards and knowledge of ConocoPhillips and the oil and gas industry. [Page 34] Materials provided to new directors include information on ConocoPhillips’ strategic plans, financial matters, corporate governance practices, Code of Business Ethics and Conduct, and other key policies and practices. [Page 34] The onboarding process includes a series of meetings with members of senior management and their staff for deep-dive briefings on ConocoPhillips’ operations and financial strategies and SPIRIT Values. [Page 34] In addition, the orientation program includes a visit to ConocoPhillips’ headquarters, and to the extent practicable, certain significant facilities. [Page 34] Continuing Director Education Continuing director education is provided during portions of Board and committee meetings and is focused on topics necessary to assist them in fulfilling their duties, including regular reviews of compliance and corporate governance developments; business-specific learning opportunities through site visits and Board meetings; and briefing sessions on topics that present special risks and opportunities to ConocoPhillips. [Page 34] Education often takes the form of “white papers” covering timely subjects or topics. [Page 34] As part of the Board’s annual evaluation process, directors are asked to identify areas where they feel continuing education would be helpful. [Page 34] Director Education Seminars Directors may attend educational seminars and programs sponsored by external organizations. [Page 34] ConocoPhillips covers the reasonable expenses for a director’s participation in outside continuing education approved by the Committee on Directors’ Affairs. [Page 34] 34 ConocoPhillips Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 35] Board and Committee Evaluations Each year, the Board performs a rigorous full Board evaluation, and each director performs a self-evaluation and an evaluation of each of his or her peers. [Page 35] Generally, the evaluation process described below is managed by the Corporate Secretary’s office with oversight by the Committee on Directors’ Affairs. [Page 35] However, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs periodically retains an independent third party to manage the evaluation process to ensure it remains as thorough and transparent as possible. [Page 35] 1 EVALUATION QUESTIONNAIRES • Formal opportunity for directors to identify potential improvements • Solicit candid feedback from each director regarding the performance and effectiveness of the Board, its committees, and individual directors 2 INDIVIDUAL INTERVIEWS • Lead Director has an in-depth conversation with each member of the Board 3 REVIEW OF FEEDBACK • Lead Director reviews questionnaire and interview responses with Committee on Directors’ Affairs • Lead Director reviews questionnaire and interview responses with full Board in executive session 4 USE OF FEEDBACK • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs develops recommendations • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs and the Lead Director identify areas for improvement of individual directors and of the Board as a whole • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs uses the results of individual director evaluations as a part of the nomination process for the next annual meeting 5 CHANGES IMPLEMENTED • As a result of this evaluation process, the Board has strengthened its structure and procedures in the following ways over the past few years: – achieved successful transitions of committee leadership roles; – provided more materials as pre-read to improve efficiencies at meetings and allow more time for discussion and deliberation; – more robust committee reports to the full Board; – individual director coaching; and – added new highly skilled directors to enhance the Board’s composition. [Page 35] In addition to participating in the full Board evaluation, members of each committee also complete a detailed questionnaire annually to evaluate how well the committee is operating and to suggest improvements. [Page 35] Each committee’s Chair summarizes the responses and reviews them with the members of his or her respective committee. [Page 35] The Committee on Directors’ Affairs reviews these evaluation processes annually and develops any changes it deems necessary to maintain best practices. [Page 35] 35 2024 Proxy Statement Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 36] Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips The Committee on Directors’ Affairs and our Board annually review our governance structure, taking into account any changes in Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) and New York Stock Exchange (the “NYSE”) rules, as well as current best practices. [Page 36] Our Corporate Governance Guidelines address the matters shown below, among others. [Page 36] • Director qualifications • Director responsibilities • Board committees • Director access to officers, employees, and independent advisors • Director compensation and stock ownership requirements • Director orientation and continuing education • Chief Executive Officer evaluation and management succession planning • Board performance evaluations The Corporate Governance Guidelines are posted on our website under “Investors > Corporate Governance” and are available in print upon request (see “Available Information and Q&A about the Annual Meeting and Voting” beginning on page 130). [Page 36] Board Leadership Structure BOARD OVERVIEW • Chairman and Chief Executive Officer: Ryan M. [Page 36] Lance • Lead Director: Robert A. [Page 36] Niblock • Active engagement by all directors • Ten of our 12 director nominees are independent • All members of the Audit and Finance Committee, Human Resources and Compensation Committee, Public Policy and Sustainability Committee, and Committee on Directors’ Affairs are independent Annual Evaluation of Leadership Structure and Annual Election of Independent Lead Director ConocoPhillips believes that independent board oversight is an essential component of strong corporate performance and enhances stockholder value. [Page 36] The Board believes there is no single organizational model that is the best and most effective in all circumstances. [Page 36] As a result, the Board periodically considers whether the offices of Chairman and CEO should be combined or separated and who should serve in such capacities. [Page 36] Under our Corporate Governance Guidelines, our Board chooses its Chairman based on what is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 36] The Chairman and CEO may, but need not, be the same person. [Page 36] As part of its annual review and evaluation process, the Board reviews its leadership structure and whether combining or separating the roles of Chairman and CEO is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 36] Our Corporate Governance Guidelines require that, in the event the Board determines that it is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and its stockholders for the offices of Chairman and CEO to be held by the same person (or in the event the office of Chairman is not held by the CEO, but is nonetheless not independent), an independent lead director must be selected from among the non-employee directors. [Page 36] The Board will continue to reexamine its corporate governance policies and leadership structures on an ongoing basis to ensure that they continue to meet our needs. [Page 36] For the 2023 Proxy Statement, we received a stockholder proposal asking stockholders to vote in favor of requiring the Board of Directors to amend the governing documents, as necessary, to separate the role of CEO and Chairman. [Page 36] After evaluating the proposal, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs determined that it is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and its stockholders to maintain flexibility in our governing documents to allow the Board of Directors to determine what organizational model best serves the interest of our company and its stockholders. [Page 36] The proposal failed to receive significant support in 2023, with only approximately 25% of stockholders indicating support for the proposal as submitted. [Page 36] During engagements in 2023, stockholders were interested in learning about our leadership structure, and appreciated hearing about how our board has the responsibility to review the governance structure on a regular and ongoing basis, allowing for adaptability. [Page 36] Stockholders expressed support for the Board of Directors continuing to evaluate whether the combined role of Chairman and CEO is in the best interest of the Company. [Page 36] 36 ConocoPhillips [Page 37] Why We Believe in Our Leadership Structure In 2023, the Board reviewed our leadership structure and determined that continuing with a combined Chairman and CEO, with our independent Lead Director, continues to be in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 37] The Board believes its current structure and processes ensure our Chairman and CEO is in a position to guide the Board in setting priorities for ConocoPhillips and in addressing the risks and challenges we face, while also providing for robust, effective, and independent oversight of management by the Board and our independent Lead Director. [Page 37] Ryan M. [Page 37] Lance Chairman and Chief Executive Officer • Possesses extensive knowledge and deep understanding of the business and challenges we face • Facilitates timely deliberation by the Board of items of the highest priority through his day-to-day insight into our challenges and opportunities • Promotes unity and reliability through consistent leadership direction internally and externally • Serves as a bridge between the Board and management, promoting collaboration while ensuring oversight • Positioned to most effectively execute the strategy for the business to maximize stockholder value • Proven successful in leading ConocoPhillips through business cycles and major transactions, including subsequent integration of acquired businesses Robert A. [Page 37] Niblock Lead Director (Since May 2019) • Extensive experience serving on public company boards provides strong background in corporate governance • Deep understanding of our business and extensive amounts of institutional knowledge having served as an active director since 2010, including rotations on all of the Committees of the Board • Respected by management and the other Directors, promoting a collaborative environment for decision-making, while enabling strong oversight of executive leadership • Strong working relationship with our Chairman and CEO • Deeply invested in ensuring the effectiveness and independence of the Board, holding in-depth conversations with each Director as part of the annual evaluation process The Board consists of ten independent directors. [Page 37] Furthermore, each of the Audit and Finance, Human Resources and Compensation, and Directors’ Affairs committees is made up entirely of independent directors. [Page 37] The Chairs of the Board’s committees establish their agendas and review their committee materials in advance of meetings, conferring with other directors and members of management as each deems appropriate. [Page 37] Moreover, each director is free to suggest agenda items and to raise matters that are not on the agenda at Board and committee meetings. [Page 37] Our Corporate Governance Guidelines require our Lead Director to preside over an executive session of the non-employee directors at every meeting. [Page 37] Each executive session may include a discussion of the performance of the Chairman and CEO, matters concerning the relationship of the Board with the Chairman and CEO and other members of senior management, and such other matters as the non-employee directors deem appropriate. [Page 37] In addition, our Lead Director presides over a meeting of our independent directors at least once a year as required by the NYSE rules. [Page 37] No formal action of the Board is taken at these meetings, although the non-employee directors may subsequently recommend matters for consideration by the full Board. [Page 37] The Board may invite guest attendees for the purpose of making presentations, responding to questions by the directors, or providing counsel on specific matters within their areas of expertise. [Page 37] 37 2024 Proxy Statement Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips

chunk_text: [Page 38] LEAD DIRECTOR’S RESPONSIBILITIES: • Presides at all meetings of the Board at which the Chairman is not present, including executive sessions of the Board, and manages the discussion with the Chairman following such executive sessions; • Serves as liaison between the Chairman and the non-employee directors; • Advises the Chairman of the Board’s informational needs and ensures appropriate information is provided to the Board; • In consultation with the Chairman, approves meeting agendas for the Board; • Approves meeting schedules to assure that there is sufficient time for discussion of all agenda items; • Has authority to call meetings of the non-employee directors; • Approves the retention of consultants that report directly to the Board; • Ensures that the Board’s self-assessments are conducted annually to promote efficient and effective Board performance and functioning; • Evaluates the performance of the CEO in consultation with the Chair of the Human Resources and Compensation Committee; and • If requested by stockholders, after consulting with the Chairman and CEO, ensures that he or she will be available for appropriate engagements with those stockholders. [Page 38] Board Independence The Corporate Governance Guidelines contain director independence standards that are consistent with the standards set forth in the NYSE Listed Company Manual to assist the Board in determining the independence of ConocoPhillips’ non-employee directors. [Page 38] Under such standards, the Board has determined that all non-employee directors meet the standards regarding independence set forth in the Corporate Governance Guidelines and are free of any material relationship with ConocoPhillips (either directly or indirectly as a partner, stockholder, or officer of an organization that has a relationship with ConocoPhillips). [Page 38] In making such determination, the Board specifically considered the fact that many of our directors may be directors, retired officers, and stockholders of companies with which we conduct business. [Page 38] In addition, some of our directors may serve as employees of, or consultants or advisors to, companies that do business with ConocoPhillips and its affiliates. [Page 38] In all cases, the Board determined that the nature of the business conducted and the interest of the director by virtue of such position were immaterial both to ConocoPhillips and to the director. [Page 38] In recommending that each non-employee director is independent, our Board, with input from the Committee on Directors’ Affairs, considered relationships that, while not constituting related-party transactions in which a director had a direct or indirect material interest, nonetheless involved transactions between ConocoPhillips and a company with which a director is affiliated, whether through employment status or by virtue of serving as a director. [Page 38] Included in the Committee’s review were the following transactions, which occurred in the ordinary course of business. [Page 38] In all instances, it was determined that the nature of the business conducted and the dollar amounts involved were immaterial, both to ConocoPhillips and the relevant counterparty, and fell within independence standards set forth in the ConocoPhillips Corporate Governance Guidelines and the NYSE Listed Company Manual. [Page 38] Director Matters Considered Dennis V. [Page 38] Arriola Ordinary course business transactions with Commercial Metals Company Gay Huey Evans CBE Ordinary course business transactions with Standard Chartered plc and S&P Global Inc. [Page 38] Eric D. [Page 38] Mullins Ordinary course business transactions with Greater Houston Partnership, Lime Rock Resources, and Valero Energy Company David T. [Page 38] Seaton Ordinary course business transactions with Boston Consulting Group, The Mosaic Company, and the National Association of Manufacturers 38 ConocoPhillips Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips [Page 39] Related Party Transactions In accordance with SEC and NYSE rules, we maintain a policy on related party transactions (“Related Party Transaction Policy”), which requires the Audit and Finance Committee to review all Reportable Related Party Transactions in advance. [Page 39] A Reportable Related Party Transaction is a transaction, arrangement, or relationship (or series of similar transactions, arrangements, or relationships) in which: • We (or one of our subsidiaries) was, is or will be a participant; • The aggregate amount involved exceeds $120,000 in any fiscal year; and • Any person who is, or at any time since the beginning of ConocoPhillips’ last fiscal year was, an executive officer, director, director nominee, or holder of at least 5 percent of our equity securities (each a “Covered Person”), or any of such Covered Person’s immediate family members, had, has, or will have a direct or indirect material interest. [Page 39] In accordance with the Related Party Transaction Policy, Covered Persons are required to identify business and financial affiliations involving themselves or their immediate family members that could reasonably be expected to give rise to a Reportable Related Party Transaction. [Page 39] Based on this information, our legal staff, in consultation with the finance team, performs the necessary diligence to determine whether any such Reportable Related Party Transaction exists or will exist, once completed. [Page 39] Upon determining that a transaction is or will be a Reportable Related Party Transaction, the General Counsel presents all relevant facts and circumstances to the Audit and Finance Committee, which reviews transactions for materiality and determines whether the transaction is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips, before either approving or disapproving it. [Page 39] In making its decision, the Audit and Finance Committee considers whether the transaction is on terms comparable to those that could be obtained in arm’s-length dealings with an unrelated third party and the extent of the Covered Person’s interest in the transaction, taking into account the conflicts of interest provisions of ConocoPhillips’ Code of Business Ethics and Conduct and such other factors as it believes are relevant. [Page 39] The Audit and Finance Committee shall prohibit any transactions that it determines are inconsistent with the interests of ConocoPhillips and its stockholders. [Page 39] The Audit and Finance Committee approved the following Reportable Related Party Transactions: Cameron J. [Page 39] Smith, son-in-law of William L. [Page 39] Bullock, Jr., our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, was employed in a non-executive position. [Page 39] The aggregate value of the compensation paid to Mr. [Page 39] Smith during fiscal year 2023 was approximately $346,312, consisting of salary, annual incentive (earned in fiscal 2023 and paid in fiscal 2024), and restricted stock unit awards. [Page 39] In addition, Mr. [Page 39] Smith received the standard benefits provided to other non- executive ConocoPhillips employees for his services during fiscal year 2023. [Page 39] Timothy A. [Page 39] Leach serves as a director and also an employee of the company, but not as an executive officer. [Page 39] Mr. [Page 39] Leach receives compensation from the company for the services he provides as an employee. [Page 39] Mr. [Page 39] Leach does not receive any additional compensation for his service as a director. [Page 39] The compensation he received as an employee is summarized in footnote 1 beginning on page 55. [Page 39] 39 2024 Proxy Statement Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips [Page 40] Board Meetings and Committees The Board met five times in 2023. [Page 40] Each director attended at least 75 percent of the aggregate of the Board and applicable committee meetings held in 2023. [Page 40] The Board has five standing committees: (1) the Executive Committee; (2) the Audit and Finance Committee; (3) the Human Resources and Compensation Committee; (4) the Committee on Directors’ Affairs; and (5) the Public Policy and Sustainability Committee. [Page 40] The Board determined that all of the members of the Audit and Finance Committee, the Human Resources and Compensation Committee, the Public Policy and Sustainability Committee, and the Committee on Directors’ Affairs are independent directors within the meaning of SEC regulations, the listing standards of the NYSE, and ConocoPhillips’ Corporate Governance Guidelines. [Page 40] Each committee, other than the Executive Committee, conducts an annual self-evaluation as described under “Board and Committee Evaluations” on page 35. [Page 40] The charters for our standing committees can be found on ConocoPhillips’ website at www.conocophillips.com under “Investors > Corporate Governance > Committees.” Stockholders may request printed copies of these charters by following the instructions under “Available Information and Q&A About the Annual Meeting and Voting” beginning on page 130. [Page 40] The committee memberships as of May 13, 2024 and the respective primary responsibilities of each committee, as well as the number of meetings each committee held in 2023, are shown below. [Page 40] Executive 2023 meetings | 1 Ryan M. [Page 40] Lance | Chair Jeffrey A. [Page 40] Joerres Eric D. [Page 40] Mullins Arjun N. [Page 40] Murti Robert A. [Page 40] Niblock Primary responsibilities • Exercises the authority of the full Board between Board meetings on all matters other than: (1) those matters expressly delegated to another committee of the Board; (2) the adoption, amendment, or repeal of any of our By-Laws; and (3) matters that cannot be delegated to a committee under statute or our Certificate of Incorporation or By-Laws. [Page 40] Audit and Finance 2023 meetings | 9 Arjun N. [Page 40] Murti | Chair Dennis V. [Page 40] Arriola William H. [Page 40] McRaven Sharmila Mulligan Eric D. [Page 40] Mullins R.A. [Page 40] Walker Primary responsibilities • Discusses with management, the independent auditors, and the internal auditors the integrity of ConocoPhillips’ accounting policies, internal controls, financial statements, financial reporting practices, and select financial matters, including our capital structure, complex financial transactions, financial risk management, retirement plans, and tax planning. [Page 40] • Reviews the qualifications, independence, and performance of our independent auditors and the qualifications and performance of our internal auditors and chief compliance officer. [Page 40] • Reviews our compliance with legal and regulatory requirements and corporate governance, including our Code of Business Ethics and Conduct. [Page 40] • Discusses with management and the chief compliance officer the implementation and effectiveness of ConocoPhillips’ global compliance and ethics program. [Page 40] • Maintains open and direct lines of communication with the Board and our management, internal auditors, independent auditors, and the global compliance and ethics organization. [Page 40] • Assists the Board in fulfilling its oversight of enterprise risk management, particularly with regard to: (1) market-based risks; (2) financial reporting; (3) effectiveness of information systems and cybersecurity; and (4) commercial trading. [Page 40] • Reviews, and coordinates the review by other committees of, significant corporate risk exposures and steps management has taken to monitor, control, and report such exposures. [Page 40] 40 ConocoPhillips Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips [Page 41] Human Resources and Compensation 2023 meetings | 7 Jeffrey A. [Page 41] Joerres | Chair Dennis V. [Page 41] Arriola Gay Huey Evans CBE Sharmila Mulligan Arjun N. [Page 41] Murti Robert A. [Page 41] • Assists the Board in discharging its responsibilities relating to the fair and competitive compensation of our executives and other key employees. [Page 41] • Together with the Lead Director, annually reviews the performance of the CEO. [Page 41] • Annually reviews and determines compensation for the CEO and our Senior Officers. [Page 41] • Reviews and reports to the Board annually on the succession-planning process for the CEO and senior management. [Page 41] • Reviews and makes recommendations to the Board regarding human capital strategies, such as leadership development; cultural; and Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (“DEI”) management. [Page 41] • Oversees our compliance with SEC rules and regulations regarding stockholder approval of certain executive compensation matters. [Page 41] • Assists the Board in fulfilling its oversight of enterprise risk management, particularly risks in connection with compensation programs and practices and retention strategies. [Page 41] Directors’ Affairs 2023 meetings | 5 Robert A. [Page 41] Niblock | Chair Gay Huey Evans CBE Jeffrey A. [Page 41] Joerres David T. [Page 41] Seaton Primary responsibilities • Selects and recommends director candidates to be submitted for election at the Annual Meeting and to fill any vacancies on the Board. [Page 41] • Recommends committee assignments to the Board. [Page 41] • Reviews and recommends to the Board compensation and benefits policies for non-employee directors. [Page 41] • Monitors the orientation and continuing education programs for directors. [Page 41] • Conducts an annual assessment of the qualifications and performance of the Board and each of the directors. [Page 41] • Assists the Board in fulfilling its oversight of enterprise risk management, particularly risks in connection with Board succession planning, stockholder matters, and governance policies and procedures. [Page 41] Public Policy and Sustainability 2023 meetings | 5 Eric D. [Page 41] Mullins | Chair William H. [Page 41] McRaven David T. [Page 41] Seaton R.A. [Page 41] Walker Primary responsibilities • Advises the Board on current and emerging domestic and international public policy issues. [Page 41] • Assists the Board in developing and reviewing policies and budgets for charitable and political contributions. [Page 41] • Reviews and makes recommendations to the Board on, and monitors compliance with, policies, programs, and practices with regard to health, safety, security (excluding cybersecurity), environmental protection, sustainable development and climate-related trends and risks, operations risk management, government relations, political/regulatory risk management, and similar matters. [Page 41] • Assists the Board in fulfilling its oversight of enterprise risk management, particularly risks in connection with political, safety, sustainable development (social and environmental), and climate-related issues or trends that affect the company and risks related to operational integrity and public policy aspects of our business and the communities where we operate. [Page 41] 41 2024 Proxy Statement Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips [Page 42] Board Oversight of Risk Management The Board has broad oversight for our risk-management programs. [Page 42] In this role, the Board is responsible for ensuring that the risk-management processes designed and implemented by management are functioning as intended and that necessary steps are taken to foster a culture of prudent decision-making throughout the organization. [Page 42] In order to maintain effective Board oversight across the entire enterprise, the Board delegates to individual committees certain elements of its oversight function, as shown below. [Page 42] In addition, the Board delegates authority to the Audit and Finance Committee to manage the risk oversight efforts of the various committees. [Page 42] As part of this authority, the Audit and Finance Committee regularly discusses ConocoPhillips’ enterprise risk-management policies and facilitates appropriate coordination among committees to ensure that our risk-management programs are functioning properly. [Page 42] The Board receives regular updates from its committees on individual categories of risk, including strategy, reputation, operations, climate change, people, technology, investment, political, legislative, regulatory, and market, and receives a report periodically from the Chair of the Audit and Finance Committee about oversight efforts and coordination. [Page 42] Senior Management ConocoPhillips’ senior management is responsible for day-to-day management of risk, including designing and implementing risk management processes and policies to address the various exposures to risk. [Page 42] Senior management regularly reports to the Board and its committees on a variety of risks. [Page 42] Board of Directors Audit and Finance Committee • Financial/reserve reporting • Compliance and ethics • Cybersecurity • Litigation and tax matters Human Resources and Compensation Committee • Retention • Compensation programs • Diversity, equity, and inclusion • Executive succession planning Committee on Directors’ Affairs • Board succession planning • Stockholder matters • Corporate governance policies and procedures Public Policy and Sustainability Committee • Health and safety • Sustainability and climate-related issues • Operational integrity • Political and regulatory The Audit and Finance Committee manages and coordinates risk oversight efforts of all committees The Board exercises its oversight function with respect to all material risks to ConocoPhillips, which are identified and discussed in our public filings with the SEC. [Page 42] 42 ConocoPhillips Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips

qa_pairs.question: What is a Reportable Related Party Transaction?
qa_pairs.answer: It is a transaction, arrangement, or relationship (or series of similar transactions, arrangements, or relationships) in which: We (or one of our subsidiaries) was, is or will be a participant; The aggregate amount involved exceeds $120,000 in any fiscal year; and Any person who is, or at any time since the beginning of ConocoPhillips’ last fiscal year was, an executive officer, director, director nominee, or holder of at least 5 percent of our equity securities (each a “Covered Person”), or any of such Covered Person’s immediate family members, had, has, or will have a direct or indirect material interest.

qa_pairs.question: What does the Audit and Finance Committee consider when determining whether a transaction is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips?
qa_pairs.answer: The Audit and Finance Committee considers whether the transaction is on terms comparable to those that could be obtained in arm’s-length dealings with an unrelated third party and the extent of the Covered Person’s interest in the transaction, taking into account the conflicts of interest provisions of ConocoPhillips’ Code of Business Ethics and Conduct and such other factors as it believes are relevant.

qa_pairs.question: How many times did the Board meet in 2023?
qa_pairs.answer: The Board met five times in 2023.

qa_pairs.question: What are the five standing committees of the Board?
qa_pairs.answer: The five standing committees are: (1) the Executive Committee; (2) the Audit and Finance Committee; (3) the Human Resources and Compensation Committee; (4) the Committee on Directors’ Affairs; and (5) the Public Policy and Sustainability Committee.

qa_pairs.question: Who exercises the authority of the full Board between Board meetings?
qa_pairs.answer: The Executive Committee exercises the authority of the full Board between Board meetings on all matters other than: (1) those matters expressly delegated to another committee of the Board; (2) the adoption, amendment, or repeal of any of our By-Laws; and (3) matters that cannot be delegated to a committee under statute or our Certificate of Incorporation or By-Laws.

qa_pairs.question: What are some of the primary responsibilities of the Audit and Finance Committee?
qa_pairs.answer: The Audit and Finance Committee discusses with management, the independent auditors, and the internal auditors the integrity of ConocoPhillips’ accounting policies, internal controls, financial statements, financial reporting practices, and select financial matters, including our capital structure, complex financial transactions, financial risk management, retirement plans, and tax planning. It also reviews the qualifications, independence, and performance of our independent auditors and the qualifications and performance of our internal auditors and chief compliance officer. The committee also reviews our compliance with legal and regulatory requirements and corporate governance, including our Code of Business Ethics and Conduct.

qa_pairs.question: What are some of the primary responsibilities of the Human Resources and Compensation Committee?
qa_pairs.answer: The Human Resources and Compensation Committee oversees our executive compensation policies, plans, programs, and practices and reviews our retention strategies. It also assists the Board in discharging its responsibilities relating to the fair and competitive compensation of our executives and other key employees. Together with the Lead Director, the committee annually reviews the performance of the CEO. Additionally, it reviews and reports to the Board annually on the succession-planning process for the CEO and senior management.

qa_pairs.question: What are some of the primary responsibilities of the Committee on Directors’ Affairs?
qa_pairs.answer: The Committee on Directors’ Affairs selects and recommends director candidates to be submitted for election at the Annual Meeting and to fill any vacancies on the Board. It also recommends committee assignments to the Board, reviews and recommends to the Board compensation and benefits policies for non-employee directors, monitors the orientation and continuing education programs for directors, and conducts an annual assessment of the qualifications and performance of the Board and each of the directors.

qa_pairs.question: What are some of the primary responsibilities of the Public Policy and Sustainability Committee?
qa_pairs.answer: The Public Policy and Sustainability Committee advises the Board on current and emerging domestic and international public policy issues. It assists the Board in developing and reviewing policies and budgets for charitable and political contributions. It also reviews and makes recommendations to the Board on, and monitors compliance with, policies, programs, and practices with regard to health, safety, security (excluding cybersecurity), environmental protection, sustainable development and climate-related trends and risks, operations risk management, government relations, political/regulatory risk management, and similar matters.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Lead Director responsible for?
qa_pairs.answer: The Lead Director’s responsibilities include presiding at Board meetings when the Chairman is absent, serving as liaison between the Chairman and non-employee directors, advising the Chairman on informational needs of the Board, approving meeting agendas and schedules with the Chairman, calling meetings of non-employee directors, approving consultants reporting to the Board, ensuring annual Board self-assessments, evaluating CEO performance with the HR committee chair, and being available for stockholder engagements.

qa_pairs.question: What standards does the Board use to determine director independence?
qa_pairs.answer: The Corporate Governance Guidelines contain director independence standards that are consistent with the standards set forth in the NYSE Listed Company Manual to assist the Board in determining the independence of ConocoPhillips’ non-employee directors.

qa_pairs.question: What is the role of the Audit and Finance Committee regarding risk management?
qa_pairs.answer: The Audit and Finance Committee manages and coordinates risk oversight efforts of all committees.
