[Page 105] Pension Benefits Our defined benefit pension plan for U.S. [Page 105] based employees is the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan (“CPRP”). [Page 105] The CPRP is intended to be tax-qualified under section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. [Page 105] Our NEOs also participate in the nonqualified ConocoPhillips Key Employee Supplemental Retirement Plan (“KESRP”). [Page 105] The CPRP consists of multiple titles with different terms, each corresponding to a different pension formula. [Page 105] NEOs are only eligible to participate in one title at any time but may have frozen benefits under one or more other titles. [Page 105] Benefits are identified by title in the table below, and all NEOs are vested in their benefits under the CPRP. [Page 105] Each title allows for payment in the form of several annuity types or a single lump sum, but all of the options are considered actuarially equivalent. [Page 105] Effective January 1, 2019, the CPRP was closed to additional benefit accrual for new hires and rehires who instead are eligible for an enhanced benefit under the ConocoPhillips Savings Plan and a related make-up plan. [Page 105] Normal retirement for all of the CPRP titles is defined as the later of age 65 or the employment termination date, but participants in Title II may receive their vested benefits upon termination of employment at any age. [Page 105] Under Title I, early retirement can occur at age 55 with five years of service. [Page 105] Under Title IV, early retirement can occur at age 50 with ten years of service. [Page 105] Under Title I, early retirement benefits are unreduced for benefits that commence at or after age 60, but are reduced by five percent per year (prorated by month) for each year before age 60 that benefits are paid. [Page 105] Under Title IV, early retirement benefits are unreduced for benefits that commence at or after age 60, but are reduced by five percent per year (prorated by month) for each year from age 50 to age 57 that benefits are paid before age 60 and four percent per year (prorated by month) for each year from age 57 that benefits are paid before age 60. [Page 105] Messrs. [Page 105] Lance, Bullock, and Olds were eligible for early retirement at the end of 2023 under the terms of Title I or Title IV, as applicable. [Page 105] The annual pension benefit under Title I and Title IV is an amount payable in the form of a single life annuity beginning at normal or early retirement equal to 1.6% multiplied by the participant’s pension compensation multiplied by years of credited service, minus a Social Security benefit offset equal to 1.5% multiplied by the participant’s annual primary Social Security benefit multiplied by years of credited service. [Page 105] For Title I, pension compensation is calculated using the three highest consecutive years in the last ten years before retirement. [Page 105] For Title IV, pension compensation is calculated using the higher of the highest consecutive 36- months of compensation or the highest nonconsecutive three years of compensation. [Page 106] 106 ConocoPhillips Executive Compensation Tables Eligible pension compensation is limited to the annual maximum permitted under the Internal Revenue Code and generally includes salary and annual incentive compensation and other items (such as overtime) that are not applicable to or are not material for our NEOs. [Page 106] Under Title I, if an executive receives layoff benefits, eligible pension compensation includes annualized salary for the year of layoff, rather than actual salary, and years of credited service are increased by the layoff benefit period. [Page 106] Pension benefits under Title II are based on monthly pay and interest credits to a notional cash balance account. [Page 106] Pay credits are equal to a percentage of eligible pension compensation as described above. [Page 106] Participants whose combined age and years of service total less than 44 receive a 6% pay credit, those whose combined age and years of service total 44 through 65 receive a 7% pay credit, and those whose combined age and years of service total 66 or more receive a 9% pay credit. [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon began participating in Title II of CPRP when he transferred to the U.S. [Page 106] payroll. [Page 106] Previously while he was on the U.K. [Page 106] payroll, he participated in the ConocoPhillips Pension Plan (the “U.K. [Page 106] Plan”). [Page 106] The U.K. [Page 106] Plan is a U.K. [Page 106] registered plan with His Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (“HMRC”). [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon has a deferred, vested benefit under the noncontributory portion of the U.K. [Page 106] Plan. [Page 106] Under applicable provisions of the U.K. [Page 106] Plan, a member is entitled to receive full benefits upon attainment of normal pension age (60 in the case of Mr. [Page 106] Macklon) subsequent to termination. [Page 106] Early retirement may occur after reaching age 55. [Page 106] Early retirement benefits are unreduced on and after age 60, but are actuarially reduced each month before age 60 that benefits are paid. [Page 106] In general, annual pension benefits under the U.K. [Page 106] Plan are calculated as the product of 1.75% of final pensionable salary multiplied by years of credited service. [Page 106] Final pensionable salary is generally basic annual salary plus pensionable allowances earned in the 12 months before active membership in the U.K. [Page 106] Plan ends. [Page 106] The U.K. [Page 106] Plan allows participants to choose between taking a full annuity or a reduced annuity plus a lump sum allowance of up to 25 percent of the value of the benefit (capped at the greater of £268,275, or 25% of the protected lifetime allowance in effect when the allowance was prospectively eliminated in 2023). [Page 106] Both choices are actuarially equivalent. [Page 106] The KESRP is designed to replace benefits that would otherwise not be received due to certain voluntary reductions of compensation under the Key Employee Deferred Compensation Plan of ConocoPhillips (“KEDCP”) and to limitations contained in the Internal Revenue Code that apply to the CPRP. [Page 106] The KESRP determines a benefit without regard to such limits, and then reduces that benefit by the amount of benefit payable from the CPRP. [Page 106] Thus, in operation the combined benefits payable from the related plans for an eligible employee equal the benefit that would have been paid if there had been no KEDCP deferrals or limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code. [Page 106] For participants in Title I of the CPRP, the KESRP pension compensation is calculated using the three highest annual amounts for salary and VCIP in the last ten calendar years before retirement plus the year of retirement. [Page 106] Applicable pension compensation for participants in Title II and Title IV of the CPRP, is calculated on the same basis as for the CPRP. [Page 106] Benefits under the KESRP are generally paid in a single lump sum at the later of age 55 or six months after separation from service. [Page 106] When payment is made, interest at then-current six-month Treasury-bill rates will be credited on any delayed benefits. [Page 106] Distribution may also be made upon a determination of death or disability. [Page 106] Each of the NEOs who are eligible for benefits in the KESRP is vested. [Page 106] Benefits due under the KESRP are paid from ConocoPhillips’ general assets, although we also maintain grantor trusts that may be used to pay such benefits. [Page 106] The trusts and the funds held in them are assets of ConocoPhillips. [Page 106] In the event of bankruptcy or insolvency of the company, trust assets would be held for the benefit of the company’s general creditors, and participants would be unsecured general creditors. [Page 106] For participants in the U.K. [Page 106] Plan, there is a plan similar to the KESRP, known as the ConocoPhillips Unfunded Pension Plan (“U.K Unfunded Plan”), which operates on the same principles but with respect to limits imposed through HMRC on registered plans like the U.K. [Page 106] Plan. [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon is a participant in the U.K. [Page 106] Unfunded Plan with regard to the time he worked in the U.K. [Page 106] from September 1, 2013 to December 31, 2016, at which time he transferred to the U.S. [Page 106] payroll (Mr. [Page 106] Macklon was a participant in the U.K. [Page 106] Plan prior to September 1, 2013). [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon is vested in his benefit under the U.K. [Page 106] Unfunded Plan, and such benefit is payable when he attains 55 years of age in the form of a lump sum, or series of lump sums payable over a five- or ten-year period. [Page 107] Nonqualified Deferred Compensation Our NEOs participate in two nonqualified deferred compensation plans, the Key Employee Deferred Compensation Plan of ConocoPhillips (“KEDCP”) and the Defined Contribution Make-Up Plan of ConocoPhillips (“DCMP”). [Page 107] The KEDCP permits participants to defer up to 50% of base salary, 100% of VCIP and 100% of cash settled PSP awards for performance periods ending in 2015 or later. [Page 107] Each of the NEOs is eligible to participate in, and is fully vested in, the KEDCP. [Page 107] Under the KEDCP, participants may elect for payment of deferred amounts to begin one(a) to five years after separation from service or on a specified date.(b) Payments may be received in a single lump sum payment or in annual, semiannual, or quarterly installment payments over a period of one to 15 years. [Page 107] The DCMP is a nonqualified restoration plan under which ConocoPhillips makes certain employer contributions that cannot be made in the qualified ConocoPhillips Savings Plan (“CPSP”), a defined contribution 401(k) plan, due to certain voluntary reductions of compensation under the KEDCP or due to compensation limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code. [Page 107] Employees make no contributions to the DCMP, and each of the NEOs is fully vested in the DCMP. [Page 107] Under the DCMP, participants may elect for payment of deferred amounts to begin one(a) to five years after separation from service. [Page 107] Payments may be received in a single lump sum payment or in annual, semiannual, or quarterly payments over a period of one to 15 years. summarization.introduction: This section of the 2024 proxy statement provides details on executive compensation, focusing on option exercises, stock vesting, pension benefits, and deferred compensation plans for ConocoPhillips' Named Executive Officers (NEOs). It outlines the different types of equity awards and pension plans, including both qualified and non-qualified options, and the specific terms and benefits associated with each.
summarization.main_points: The 'Option Exercises and Stock Vested' table details the number of shares acquired and their realized value for each NEO during 2023, distinguishing between option exercises and stock vesting. ConocoPhillips offers several pension plans, including the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan (CPRP), Key Employee Supplemental Retirement Plan (KESRP), and for UK employees, the ConocoPhillips Pension Plan (UK Plan) and Unfunded Pension Plan, each with specific eligibility criteria, benefit formulas, and payment options. The KESRP and UK Unfunded Plan supplement the qualified plans to address compensation deferrals and Internal Revenue Code limitations. NEOs also participate in nonqualified deferred compensation plans like the Key Employee Deferred Compensation Plan (KEDCP) and the Defined Contribution Make-Up Plan (DCMP), allowing for deferral of salary and incentive compensation, with various payment options available upon separation from service.
summarization.conclusion: The proxy statement comprehensively describes the various components of ConocoPhillips' executive compensation program, including equity awards, pension benefits, and deferred compensation, ensuring transparency for shareholders. These programs are designed to attract, retain, and incentivize top executives while adhering to relevant regulations and company policies.

qa_pairs.answer: The DCMP is a nonqualified restoration plan under which ConocoPhillips makes certain employer contributions that cannot be made in the qualified ConocoPhillips Savings Plan (CPSP) due to certain voluntary reductions of compensation under the KEDCP or due to compensation limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code.

[Page 109] In addition, specific severance arrangements for executive officers, including the NEOs, are provided under two severance plans: (1) the ConocoPhillips Executive Severance Plan (“CPESP”), which is available to a limited number of senior executives; and (2) the ConocoPhillips Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan (“CICSP”), which is also available to a limited number of senior executives but only on or following change in control. [Page 109] These arrangements are described below. [Page 109] Executives are not entitled to participate in both plans as a result of a single event. [Page 109] For example, executives receiving benefits under the CICSP would not be entitled to benefits potentially payable under the CPESP relating to the event giving rise to benefits under the CICSP. [Page 110] 110 ConocoPhillips Executive Compensation Tables ConocoPhillips Executive Severance Plan The CPESP covers executives in salary grades generally corresponding to vice president and higher and is incorporated by reference to Exhibit 10.47 to the Annual Report of ConocoPhillips on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2021; File No. [Page 110] 001-32395. [Page 110] Under the CPESP, if ConocoPhillips terminates a plan participant other than for cause, as defined in the plan, then upon executing a general release of liability and, if requested, an agreement not to compete with ConocoPhillips, the participant will be entitled to: • A lump-sum cash payment equal to one-and-a-half or two times the sum of the employee’s base salary and current target VCIP award; • For executives actively participating in the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan (CPRP) and ConocoPhillips Key Employee Supplemental Retirement Plan (KESRP), a lump-sum cash payment equal to the present value of the increase in pension benefits that would result from the crediting of an additional one-and-a-half or two years to the employee’s number of years of age and service under the applicable defined benefit pension formula under the plans; • A lump-sum cash payment equal to ConocoPhillips’ cost of certain welfare benefits for an additional one-and-a-half or two years; • Continued eligibility for a pro rata portion of the annual VCIP for the year of termination; and • Treatment as a layoff under our various compensation and equity programs. [Page 110] Generally, layoff treatment will allow full or partial vesting of awards previously made and continued eligibility under ongoing ConocoPhillips programs. [Page 110] Thus, Executive RSU awards would vest partially (for grants 6-12 months before the layoff) or fully (for grants more than 12 months before the layoff), and the executive would remain eligible for a pro rata proportion of awards attributable to ongoing performance periods under the PSP in which the executive had participated for at least one year. [Page 110] ConocoPhillips may amend or terminate the CPESP at any time. [Page 110] Amounts payable under the CPESP will be offset by any payments or benefits that are payable to the severed employee under any other plan, policy, or program of ConocoPhillips relating to severance, and amounts may also be reduced in the event of willful and bad faith conduct demonstrably injurious to ConocoPhillips, monetarily or otherwise, or, if required by law to be “clawed back,” such as may be the case in certain circumstances under the ConocoPhillips Clawback Policy. [Page 110] ConocoPhillips Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan The CICSP covers executives in salary grades generally corresponding to vice president and higher and is incorporated by reference to Exhibit 10.20.1 to the Annual Report of ConocoPhillips on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2021; File No. [Page 110] 001-32395. [Page 110] Under the CICSP, if within two years after a “change in control” of ConocoPhillips, a participant is terminated by ConocoPhillips other than for cause, or by the participant for good reason (as such terms are defined in the plan), upon executing a general release of liability, the participant will be entitled to: • A lump-sum cash payment equal to two or three times the sum of the employee’s base salary and the higher of current target VCIP compensation or the previous two years’ average VCIP compensation; • For executives actively participating in the CPRP and KESRP, a lump-sum cash payment equal to the present value of the increase in pension benefits that would result from crediting an additional two or three years to the employee’s number of years of age and service under the applicable defined benefit pension formula under the plans; • A lump-sum cash payment equal to ConocoPhillips’ cost of certain welfare benefits for an additional two or three years; and • Continued eligibility for a pro rata portion of the annual VCIP compensation for the year of termination. [Page 110] Excise tax gross-up benefits are not available under the CICSP. [Page 110] Upon a change in control, awards that an acquirer assumes or substitutes will be subject to accelerated vesting only following both the change in control and a qualifying termination of employment. [Page 110] A qualifying termination of employment includes involuntary termination not-for-cause or voluntary termination for good reason. [Page 110] Participants will continue to be able to exercise stock options for their remaining terms (up to 10 years from the date of grant). summarization.introduction: This text outlines ConocoPhillips' executive compensation, including deferred compensation plans (KEDCP and DCMP) and severance arrangements. It details the benefits payable to Named Executive Officers (NEOs) under various termination scenarios, such as involuntary termination, change in control, death, or disability.
summarization.main_points: The document explains the KEDCP and DCMP, where participants direct notional investments, impacting their returns. It describes the ConocoPhillips Executive Severance Plan (CPESP) and the Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan (CICSP), detailing eligibility, triggers (like termination without cause or change in control), and benefits such as lump-sum payments, continued benefits, and vesting of awards. The document also specifies that these severance payments may be offset by other benefits or reduced in cases of detrimental conduct or clawback policies. Furthermore, specific scenarios and estimated payouts as of December 31, 2023, are provided for several NEOs, outlining compensation components such as base salary, short-term incentives, variable cash incentive programs, restricted stock units, retirement benefits, and health & welfare benefits.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips provides structured compensation and severance packages for its executives, with specific terms and conditions governing payouts under different circumstances. These plans are subject to amendment, offset provisions, and potential clawbacks.

[Page 113] As discussed in the narrative preceding the tables above, the amounts shown indicate the difference in compensation arising from the stated type of termination in comparison to a voluntary resignation. [Page 113] A NEO who voluntarily resigns before reaching the retirement age and service eligibility threshold contained in those equity awards and compensation programs (generally age 55 with 5 years of service) would not earn awards for ongoing performance periods under the VCIP, the PSP, the Executive RSU Program, or the Stock Option Program (as applicable), and would lose prior awards under the PSP and the Executive RSU Program (or other restricted stock or RSUs) and stock options. [Page 113] If ConocoPhillips were to invoke the detrimental activity clause, amounts that would normally be paid to a retirement-eligible NEO in connection with a voluntary resignation would instead be forfeited. [Page 114] 114 ConocoPhillips Executive Compensation Tables * Notes Applicable to All Termination Tables — Benefits that would be available generally to all or substantially all salaried employees on the U.S. [Page 114] payroll are not included in the amounts shown on the previous page. [Page 114] In preparing the tables, we made the following assumptions: • Base Salary — In the event of an involuntary not-for-cause termination not related to a change in control (“regular involuntary termination”), the amount reflects two times base salary. [Page 114] In the event of an involuntary not-for-cause or good reason termination related to a change in control (“CIC termination”), the amount reflects three times base salary. [Page 114] • Variable Cash Incentive Program — In the event of a regular involuntary termination or a CIC termination, the amount reflects the employee’s pro rata current VCIP target. [Page 114] Targets for VCIP are for a full year and are pro rata for the NEOs based on time spent in their respective positions. [Page 114] • PSP and RSUs — For the performance periods related to PSP, amounts for the January 2021 – December 2023 period reflect actual payout amounts that were awarded in February 2024, except in the event of a CIC termination, the amounts reflect the higher of target or actual payout, as the award cannot be reduced following a change in control. [Page 114] Amounts for other ongoing PSP performance periods are shown at target, including any adjustments for promotion or demotion made since the target awards were granted. [Page 114] For awards under the Executive RSU Program, amounts reflect actual units granted. [Page 114] • Incremental Retirement Values — For all NEOs, the amounts reflect the single sum, discounted to a present value, of the increment due to an additional two years of age and service with associated pension compensation in the event of a regular involuntary termination (three years in the event of a CIC termination), regardless of whether the value is provided directly through a defined benefit plan or through the relevant severance plan. [Page 115] 2024 Proxy Statement 115 CEO Pay Ratio ConocoPhillips’ compensation and benefits philosophy and the overall structure of our compensation and benefit programs are designed to reward all employees who contribute to our success. [Page 115] We strive to ensure the compensation of every employee reflects their talents, skills, responsibilities, and experience and is competitive within our peer group. [Page 115] Compensation and benefits are benchmarked and set to be market-competitive in the employees’ home payroll country. [Page 115] Under rules adopted pursuant to the Dodd-Frank Act, ConocoPhillips is required to calculate and disclose the total compensation paid to its median employee, as well as the ratio of total compensation paid to the median employee as compared to the total compensation paid to the CEO. [Page 115] The paragraphs that follow describe our methodology and the resulting CEO pay ratio. [Page 115] The ratio of pay of the CEO compared to that of the median employee was approximately 101 to one in 2023. [Page 115] The annual total compensation of the CEO was $20,789,282. [Page 115] The estimated median of the annual total compensation of all ConocoPhillips employees other than the CEO, as represented by the annual total compensation of a median employee, was $205,547. [Page 115] The compensation of the CEO and the median employee were determined using the same rules we followed in preparing the Summary Compensation Table on page 98, except the compensation of the CEO and median employee were adjusted to include nondiscriminatory health and welfare benefits totaling $18,609 and $16,764, respectively. [Page 115] ConocoPhillips had approximately 10,045 employees worldwide (including intermittent and temporary employees) as of the determination date (December 31, 2023). [Page 115] To identify the “median employee,” we excluded employees from six countries, representing in total approximately 2.3 percent, or 233 employees worldwide. [Page 115] After excluding such employees and the CEO, we determined the pay ratio using the remaining approximately 9,811 employees. [Page 115] The chart below shows the countries from which employees were excluded and the approximate number of employees from each such country. [Page 115] Payroll Country Excluded Number of Employees Excluded Malaysia 86 China 81 Singapore 31 Qatar 24 Libya 9 Japan 2 For the remaining employees, we used a consistently applied compensation measure that management believes reasonably reflects the annual compensation of employees and includes elements of compensation distributed widely among employees. [Page 115] Those elements were base salary, overtime, annual incentive compensation (VCIP) at target, equity awards, and certain country-specific allowances. [Page 115] We used data as of December 31, 2023, to identify ConocoPhillips employees and to determine the consistently applied compensation measure for those employees. [Page 115] Data not denominated in U.S. [Page 115] dollars was converted to U.S. [Page 115] dollars using an average monthly conversion rate for each denomination during 2023. [Page 115] Data came from ConocoPhillips’ payroll records. [Page 115] We did not make any adjustments to the data to account for differences in cost of living in any of the countries in which we have employees. [Page 115] The SEC rules for identifying the median employee and calculating the pay ratio based on that employee’s annual total compensation allow companies to adopt a variety of methodologies, to apply certain exclusions, and to make reasonable estimates and assumptions that reflect their compensation practices. summarization.introduction: This document presents ConocoPhillips' executive compensation details, including benefits and payments upon termination, and the ratio of CEO pay to median employee pay. It also outlines the 'Compensation Actually Paid' (CAP) to executives and its reconciliation with Summary Compensation Table (SCT) totals, as required by the Dodd-Frank Act.
summarization.main_points: The executive compensation tables detail payments for involuntary termination (both with and without a change in control), death, and disability. Assumptions used to prepare the tables, like the base salary and short-term incentive calculations under different termination scenarios, are clarified. The document also presents the CEO pay ratio, revealing that the CEO's compensation was approximately 101 times that of the median employee in 2023, detailing the methodology used to determine the median employee and any exclusions applied. Furthermore, it analyzes the "Compensation Actually Paid" (CAP) to the CEO and other NEOs (Named Executive Officers), reconciling it with SCT totals and highlighting the important financial performance measure used to link company performance and executive compensation.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips discloses its executive compensation practices and pay ratios in compliance with regulatory requirements, emphasizing its compensation philosophy and methodology for determining executive and employee pay. The document provides a detailed view of executive compensation components and their relationship to company performance.

summarization.introduction: This document provides information regarding ConocoPhillips' equity compensation plans as of December 31, 2023, and includes two stockholder proposals to be presented at the Annual Meeting. It details the number of securities to be issued, exercise prices, and remaining availability for future issuance under existing equity compensation plans, as well as the proposals concerning a simple majority vote requirement and revisiting pay incentives for GHG emission reductions.
summarization.main_points: The equity compensation plan information outlines the approved plans, the number of securities to be issued upon exercise of options, the weighted average exercise price, and the number of securities remaining available for future issuance, emphasizing that no additional awards can be granted under the older plans after the 2023 Omnibus Stock and Performance Incentive Plan approval. It addresses the treatment of restricted stock and restricted stock units (RSUs), dividend equivalents, and the vesting schedules for various employee groups, including executives, and also mentions adjustments made following mergers and acquisitions. The first stockholder proposal (Item 4) requests a shift to a simple majority vote requirement in the company's charter and bylaws, while the second stockholder proposal (Item 5) advocates for revisiting pay incentives tied to GHG emission reductions, arguing that climate change scenarios are often overstated.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips' board supports the stockholder proposal regarding a simple majority vote, while the proposal regarding pay incentives for GHG emissions reductions is presented for consideration. The details provided are essential for shareholders to make informed decisions during the Annual Meeting.

chunk_text: [Page 128] Supporting Statement: Despite the evidence that climate alarmism is overstated, ConocoPhillips’s executive pay program incorporates unnecessary incentives to assumed combat climate change. [Page 128] • According to the Company’s 2023 Proxy Statement, the Human Resources and Compensation Committee set a Variable Cash Incentive Program target of 14 percent of total compensation for the CEO and 16 percent for other Named Executive Officers.12 • “Strategic and ESG Milestones” are one of the five metrics used to determine VCIP for NEOs. [Page 128] These milestones include: - “Demonstrated meaningful progress toward our Paris-aligned climate risk framework.” - “Progressed our long-term strategy by establishing new methane and flaring targets, executing emission reduction projects, and progressing CCS business development opportunities.” These VCIP metrics are unscientific and create a breach of fiduciary duty. [Page 128] ConocoPhillips is an oil and gas company and should focus on what it does best. [Page 128] The company cannot afford to be left behind because of misguided executive pay incentives. [Page 128] Resolved: Shareholders of ConocoPhillips request the Board of Directors’ Human Resources and Compensation Committee to revisit its incentive guidelines for executive pay, to emphasize legitimate fiduciary goals and consider eliminating greenhouse gas reduction targets and other scientifically dubious goals from compensation inducements. [Page 128] What vote is required to approve this proposal? [Page 128] Approval of this proposal requires the affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or represented by proxy at the Annual Meeting and entitled to vote on the proposal. [Page 128] WHAT DOES THE BOARD RECOMMEND? [Page 128] The Board recommends you vote AGAINST this proposal for the following reasons: The Board has carefully considered the recommendations set forth in the proposal and we believe the changes suggested are not in the best interest of ConocoPhillips or our stockholders for the following reasons: Our executive compensation is aligned with our company strategy and with the long-term interests of our stockholders. [Page 128] ConocoPhillips continues to be guided by our value proposition of superior returns to stockholders through price cycles while executing against our Triple Mandate, which sets out three objectives to align our actions with the underlying realities of our business and demonstrates our commitment to create long-term value for our stockholders. [Page 128] Our Triple Mandate includes reliably and responsibly delivering oil and gas production to meet energy transition pathway demand, delivering returns on and of capital for our stockholders, and remaining focused on achieving our net-zero operational emissions ambition. [Page 128] Consistent with our philosophy of aligning our executive compensation programs with company strategy and with the long-term interests of our stockholders, our executive compensation programs and metrics remain aligned with our value proposition and Triple Mandate (see page 72). [Page 128] An overwhelming majority of our stockholders have expressed a desire for us to link compensation with our climate commitments. [Page 128] We regularly meet with stockholders on a variety of topics, including our executive compensation programs. [Page 128] In recent years, during these engagements, an overwhelming majority of stockholders have sought to confirm how we link progress on our climate commitments to our executive compensation programs. [Page 128] Recently, ConocoPhillips created a separately weighted measure (10 percent) for “Energy Transition Milestones,” for our short-term incentive program (see page 82), and almost all of our stockholders supported our modified compensation program. [Page 128] For more information on our stockholder engagement, see “Stockholder Engagement and Board Responsiveness” beginning on page 45 and “2023 Say on Pay Vote Result, Stockholder Engagement, and Board Responsiveness” beginning on page 69. [Page 128] AGAINST For the foregoing reasons, the Board recommends you vote AGAINST this stockholder proposal. summarization.introduction: This document analyzes a stockholder proposal for ConocoPhillips to revisit its executive pay incentives, specifically regarding greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction targets. The proposal argues that these targets are unscientific and create a breach of fiduciary duty.
summarization.main_points: The stockholder proposal requests the Board of Directors' Human Resources and Compensation Committee to revise executive pay guidelines, emphasizing fiduciary goals and eliminating GHG reduction targets. The company's executive pay program currently incorporates incentives tied to climate change mitigation, with "Strategic and ESG Milestones" as a metric in the Variable Cash Incentive Program (VCIP) for Named Executive Officers (NEOs). The Board of Directors recommends voting against the proposal, arguing that executive compensation aligns with the company's strategy, long-term stockholder interests, and the Triple Mandate, which includes achieving net-zero operational emissions. The Board highlights that an overwhelming majority of stockholders have expressed support for linking compensation to climate commitments and that the company has already created a separate measure for "Energy Transition Milestones" in its short-term incentive program. The document also provides details on submitting future stockholder proposals, proxy access nominations, and attending the virtual annual meeting, along with voting procedures for both record and beneficial stockholders.
summarization.conclusion: The stockholder proposal to revisit executive pay incentives related to GHG emission reductions is opposed by the Board, who believe the current compensation structure is aligned with company strategy and stockholder interests. The vote required to approve the proposal is the affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or represented by proxy at the Annual Meeting.

[Page 136] 136 ConocoPhillips Available Information and Q&A About the Annual Meeting and Voting [Page 137] Appendix A Non-GAAP Financial Measures Adjusted Earnings Adjusted Earnings is calculated by removing the impact of special items from reported earnings. [Page 137] Special items are items that management believes are unusual or nonrecurring and not indicative of our core operating results or business outlook over the long term. [Page 137] Management believes adjusted earnings is useful to investors in evaluating our operating results, understanding our operating trends across periods on a consistent basis, and providing comparability with the performance of peer companies. [Page 137] Adjusted EPS Adjusted EPS is a measure of the company’s diluted net earnings per share excluding special items. [Page 137] Special items are items that management believes are unusual or nonrecurring and not indicative of our core operating results or business outlook over the long term. [Page 137] Management believes adjusted earnings per share is useful to investors in evaluating our operating results, understanding our operating trends across periods on a consistent basis and providing comparability with the performance of peer companies. [Page 137] Cash from Operations (CFO) Cash from operations (CFO) is calculated by removing the impact from operating working capital from cash provided by operating activities. [Page 137] The company believes that the non-GAAP measure cash from operations is useful to investors to help understand changes in cash provided by operating activities excluding the impact of working capital changes across periods on a consistent basis and with the performance of peer companies in a manner that, when viewed in combination with the company’s results prepared in accordance with GAAP, provides a more complete understanding of the factors and trends affecting the company’s business and performance. [Page 137] Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) Return on capital employed (ROCE) is a measure of the profitability of the company’s capital employed in its business operations compared with that of its peers. [Page 137] The company calculates ROCE as a ratio, the numerator of which is net income, and the denominator of which is average total equity plus average total debt. [Page 137] The net income is adjusted for after-tax interest expense, for the purposes of measuring efficiency of debt capital used in operations; net income is also adjusted for non-operational or special items impacts to allow for comparability in the long-term view across periods. qa_pairs.question: How does ConocoPhillips define Adjusted Earnings?
qa_pairs.answer: Adjusted Earnings is calculated by removing the impact of special items from reported earnings.

qa_pairs.question: How does ConocoPhillips define Free Cash Flow?
qa_pairs.answer: Free Cash Flow is defined as cash from operations net of capital expenditures and investments.

qa_pairs.question: What is Cost of Supply?
qa_pairs.answer: Cost of supply is the WTI equivalent price that generates a 10 percent after-tax return on a point-forward and fully burdened basis. Fully burdened includes capital infrastructure, foreign exchange, price-related inflation, G&A, and carbon tax (if currently assessed). If no carbon tax exists for the asset, carbon pricing aligned with internal energy scenarios is applied. All barrels of resource in the cost of supply calculation are discounted at 10 percent.

qa_pairs.question: How does ConocoPhillips define Return on Capital Employed (ROCE)?
qa_pairs.answer: Return on capital employed (ROCE) is a measure of the profitability of the company’s capital employed in its business operations compared with that of its peers. The company calculates ROCE as a ratio, the numerator of which is net income, and the denominator of which is average total equity plus average total debt. The net income is adjusted for after-tax interest expense, for the purposes of measuring efficiency of debt capital used in operations; net income is also adjusted for non-operational or special items impacts to allow for comparability in the long-term view across periods.

summarization.main_points: ConocoPhillips aims to provide superior returns through disciplined investments and distributions, leveraging a diverse and durable portfolio. They use a rigorous capital allocation framework and cost of supply analysis to inform investment decisions, balancing short-cycle unconventional assets with longer-cycle conventional assets. A key component of their strategy involves improving their environmental performance, including accelerating their GHG-intensity reduction target through 2030 and pursuing a pathway to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. They are also focused on maintaining a strong balance sheet and actively managing their portfolio through strategic acquisitions and divestitures.

summarization.introduction: The document discusses ConocoPhillips' strategy, focusing on LNG as a crucial fuel for the energy transition and its durable returns-focused value proposition. It highlights the company's diversified portfolio, low-cost supply, and growing distribution capacity.
summarization.main_points: ConocoPhillips emphasizes LNG's role in reducing carbon emissions compared to coal, supported by a strong LNG growth outlook. The company's 10-year plan reflects a focus on free cash flow (FCF) and capital discipline, underpinned by a diversified portfolio including Alaska, international operations, and unconventional resources. Key assets include Qatar LNG expansion, APLNG shareholding, Surmont, Montney, and the Willow project, with efforts to reduce emissions through technology and CCS. The Lower 48 assets, particularly in the Permian Basin, are geared towards maximizing returns through disciplined development and technological advancements. Commercial LNG opportunities are expanding, with Port Arthur LNG playing a significant role, leveraging ConocoPhillips' global marketing presence and strategic optionality.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips aims to deliver competitive returns and sustainable growth through its diverse asset base, strategic investments in LNG, and a commitment to emissions reductions, capitalizing on its commercial acumen and operational efficiencies. The company's focus on free cash flow and reinvestment rate reflects a commitment to long-term value creation.

summarization.introduction: ConocoPhillips is focused on delivering superior returns and free cash flow growth through a disciplined financial plan and strategic asset management. The company is committed to sustainability by lowering emissions and maximizing water reuse.
summarization.main_points: ConocoPhillips plans to generate significant free cash flow (FCF) over the next decade, driven by its Permian, Eagle Ford, and Bakken assets. The company aims to maintain a strong balance sheet and prioritize returns on and of capital, with a focus on increasing shareholder distributions. Technological advancements are being implemented to enhance value, lower emissions, and improve operational efficiencies across its core basins. The financial strategy is designed to be resilient through commodity price cycles, ensuring consistent execution and shareholder value.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips is committed to delivering compelling shareholder returns and remains a must-own E&P company through its strategic investments, disciplined capital allocation, and dedication to ESG excellence, ensuring durable returns and cash flow growth into the next decade.

chunk_text: [Page 61] Definitions ww Non-GAAP Measures Cash from operations (CFO) is calculated by removing the impact from operating working capital from cash provided by operating activities. [Page 61] The company believes that the non- GAAP measure cash from operations is useful to investors to help understand changes in cash provided by operating activities excluding the impact of working capital changes across periods on a consistent basis and with the performance of peer companies in a manner that, when viewed in combination with the Company's results prepared in accordance with GAAP provides a more complete understanding of the factors and trends affecting the Company's business and performance. [Page 61] Additionally, when the company estimates CFO based on sensitivities, it assumes no operating working capital changes, and therefore CFO equals cash provided by operating activities. [Page 61] Free cash flow is defined as cash from operations net of capital expenditures and investments. [Page 61] The company believes free cash flow is useful to investors in understanding how existing cash from operations is utilized as a source for sustaining our current capital plan and future development growth. [Page 61] Free cash flow is not a measure of cash available for discretionary expenditures since the company has certain non-discretionary obligations such as debt service that are not deducted from the measure. [Page 61] Net debt includes total balance sheet debt less cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments. [Page 61] The company believes this non-GAAP measure is useful to investors as it provides a measure to compare debt less cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments across periods on a consistent basis. [Page 61] Reinvestment rate defined as total capital expenditures divided by cash from operations. [Page 61] Cash from operations is a non-GAAP measure defined in this Appendix. [Page 61] The company believes reinvestment rate is useful to investors in understanding the execution of the company’s disciplined and returns-focused capital allocation strategy. [Page 61] Return on capital employed (ROCE) is a measure of the profitability of the company’s capital employed in its business operations compared with that of its peers. [Page 61] The company calculates ROCE as a ratio, the numerator of which is net income, and the denominator of which is average total equity plus average total debt. [Page 61] The net income is adjusted for after-tax interest expense, for the purposes of measuring efficiency of debt capital used in operations; net income is also adjusted for non-operational or special items impacts to allow for comparability in the long-term view across periods. [Page 61] The company believes ROCE is a good indicator of long-term company and management performance as it relates to capital efficiency, both absolute and relative to the company’s primary peer group. [Page 61] ConocoPhillips 61 [Page 62] Definitions ww Other Terms Cost of Supply is the WTI equivalent price that generates a 10% after-tax return on a point-forward and fully burdened basis. [Page 62] Fully burdened includes capital infrastructure, foreign exchange, price-related inflation, G&A and carbon tax (if currently assessed). [Page 62] If no carbon tax exists for the asset, carbon pricing aligned with internal energy scenarios are applied. [Page 62] All barrels of resource in the Cost of Supply calculation are discounted at 10%. [Page 62] Distributions is defined as the total of the ordinary dividend, share repurchases and variable return of cash (VROC). [Page 62] Also referred to as return of capital. [Page 62] Free cash flow breakeven is the WTI price at which cash from operations equals capital expenditures and investments. [Page 62] Also referred to as capital breakeven. [Page 62] Cash from operations is anon-GAAP measure defined in this Appendix. [Page 62] Leverage ratio refers to net debt divided by cash from operations. [Page 62] Net debt and cash from operations are non-GAAP measures defined in this Appendix. [Page 62] Optimized Cascade® Process is a ConocoPhillips proprietary licensed process for technology to liquefy natural gas. [Page 62] More information can be found at http://Inglicensing.conocophillips.com/what-we-do/Ing-technology/optimized-cascade-process. [Page 62] Reserve replacement is defined by the Company as a ratio representing the change in proved reserves, net of production, divided by current year production. [Page 62] The Company believes that reserve replacement is useful to investors to help understand how changes in proved reserves, net of production, compare with the Company's current year production, inclusive of acquisitions and dispositions. [Page 62] Resources: The company estimates its total resources based on the Petroleum Resources Management System (PRMS), a system developed by industry that classifies recoverable hydrocarbons into commercial and sub-commercial to reflect their status at the time of reporting. [Page 62] Proved, probable and possible reserves are classified as commercial, while remaining resources are categorized as sub-commercial or contingent. [Page 62] The company’s resource estimate includes volumes associated with both commercial and contingent categories. [Page 62] The SEC permits oil and gas companies, in their filings with the SEC, to disclose only proved, probable and possible reserves. [Page 62] U.S. [Page 62] investors are urged to consider closely the oil and gas disclosures in our Form 10-K and other reports and filings with the SEC. [Page 62] Resource life is calculated as total resource under $40 Cost of Supply divided by 2022 production. [Page 62] Return of capital is defined as the total of the ordinary dividend, share repurchases and variable return of cash (VROC). [Page 62] Also referred to as distributions. [Page 62] ConocoPhillips 62
